name: CI/CD Pipelines
description: One challenge you'll face after containerizing your application is the need to manually rebuild and push for every code change. CI/CD pipelines automate this entire process - building, testing, and deploying your application every time changes are made, ensuring a smooth and reliable development workflow.

learning_steps.description: Learn the fundamentals of continuous integration and continuous deployment.

learning_steps.title: CI vs Continuous Delivery vs Continuous Deployment
learning_steps.description: Understand the differences between continuous integration, continuous delivery, and continuous deployment.
Learn about implementing CI/CD pipelines with these tools:

Set up a basic CI/CD pipeline for your containerized application:

1. Use GitHub Actions (or your preferred tool) to automatically:
   • Build your application
   • Run tests
   • Build a Docker image
   • Push the image to a container registry
2. Configure the pipeline to trigger on code commits to your main branch
3. Add a notification system for successful deployments or failures
Basic workflow for building and pushing Docker images:
learning_steps.code:
name: Build and Push

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      
      - name: Build Docker image
        run: docker build -t myapp:${{ github.sha }} .
      
      - name: Login to Registry
        run: echo ${{ secrets.REGISTRY_PASSWORD }} | docker login -u ${{ secrets.REGISTRY_USER }} --password-stdin
      
      - name: Push image
        run: docker push myapp:${{ github.sha }}

learning_steps.description:
Implement a multi-environment deployment pipeline:

1. Deploy to staging first
2. Run automated tests against staging
3. Require manual approval for production
4. Promote to production after approval
